unnormalised: Okay, so you want to get seriously good at your sport, right? It's not just about showing up and hoping for the best. You gotta have a plan, a training regimen. Think of it like your cheat sheet for success, except you actually have to put in the work!
normalised: Okay, so you want to get seriously good at your sport, right? It is not just about showing up and hoping for the best. You got to have a plan, a training regimen. Think of it like your cheat sheet for success, except you actually have to put in the work!

unnormalised: First off, figure out your goals. Are you aiming to win the kabaddi tournament at your college, IIT Delhi, or maybe you dream of representing India in the Olympics? Your training regimen needs to reflect that ambition. A local cricket match in Mumbai needs a different prep than the Ranji Trophy.
normalised: First off, figure out your goals. Are you aiming to win the kabaddi tournament at your college, I I T Delhi, or maybe you dream of representing India in the Olympics? Your training regimen needs to reflect that ambition. A local cricket match in Mumbai needs a different prep than the Ranji Trophy.

unnormalised: Let's talk specifics. A good regimen has a few key ingredients. Firstly, strength training. We're talking hitting the gym, lifting weights. Think squats, bench presses, deadlifts – the whole shebang. Get a good trainer, especially if you're new to it. Don't wanna pull a hamstring trying to impress everyone with your weightlifting prowess. Maybe start with 3 days a week, focusing on different muscle groups. Our very own PT Usha, back in the day, supposedly had a regimen that involved running across a 500 sq ft courtyard a gazillion times!

Think squats, bench presses, deadlifts – the whole shebang. Get a good trainer, especially if you are new to it. Do not want to pull a hamstring trying to impress everyone with your weightlifting prowess. Maybe start with three days a week, focusing on different muscle groups. Our very own P T Usha, back in the day, supposedly had a regimen that involved running across a five hundred square feet courtyard a gazillion times!

unnormalised: Next, cardio. This is your endurance training. Running, cycling, swimming – whatever floats your boat (or propels you forward). If you're a marathon runner, you'll be clocking serious km every week. Remember that legend of Milkha Singh practicing relentlessly in scorching heat? That's dedication. Even if you're a chess player, cardio is important for mental stamina. Think long matches in humid Chennai!

Even if you are a chess player, cardio is important for mental stamina. Think long matches in humid Chennai!

unnormalised: Don't forget about skill-specific training. For cricket, that's net practice, fielding drills, and working on your bowling action. For badminton, it's smashing, dropping, and mastering your footwork. This is where you hone your craft.
normalised: Do not forget about skill-specific training. For cricket, that is net practice, fielding drills, and working on your bowling action. For badminton, it is smashing, dropping, and mastering your footwork. This is where you hone your craft.

unnormalised: Recovery is crucial too! This isn't some optional extra. It's essential. Rest days are important, as are proper nutrition and sleep. Dr. Sharma, the team physician for the Mumbai Indians, always emphasizes the importance of sufficient protein intake and at least 8 hours of sleep. Don't underestimate the power of a good night's sleep!

unnormalised: Finally, tailor your regimen to your individual needs. What works for Sachin Tendulkar might not work for you. Listen to your body, and don't be afraid to adjust your plan as needed. Consider hiring a coach. A good coach can provide expert guidance and help you stay on track. Some charge Rs. 5000 a month, others, a percentage of your winnings.

unnormalised: And remember, Rome wasn’t built in a day. It takes time, consistency, and hard work to achieve your goals. So, stick to your regimen, stay disciplined, and believe in yourself. Jai Hind!
